2014.name: Trucking hatchery salmon
captions: During the 2014 drought, water levels in the Sacramento River dropped so low that fall-run Chinook salmon would not survive the journey from hatcheries to the ocean. Biologists working for state and federal agencies trucked about 20 million fish from upstream hatcheries to the San Francisco Bay.

During extreme drought, the I-5 highway can become a critical part of California’s water system for migrating salmon. The trucking practice highlights the intensity of management efforts for Sacramento River fall-run Chinook salmon. Despite heroic efforts at five major hatcheries, the number of adults returning to the Sacramento River each fall has been inconsistent and at times, alarmingly low.

In 2024, the hatchery-raised juvenile salmon were released near Mare Island. Bypassing their migration route down the Sacramento River and through the Delta improved the population’s survival in the short term. Ongoing experiments will test if trucking has unintended consequences on the full lifecycle of the population.
2014.source: US Fish and Wildlife Service, Pacific Southwest Region, 2014

2014.name: Sacramento Weir sits idle
captions: The Sacramento Weir sits closed and dry in 2014. The weir protects the City of Sacramento from floods by diverting river flows into the Yolo Bypass.

2017.name: Oroville Dam emergency
captions: Oroville Dam's spillway eroded during February floods of 2017. After heavy rainfall (almost 13 inches over 4 days), floodwaters threatened to overtop the dam, forcing engineers to release massive amounts of water. As the main and emergency spillway failed, over 180,000 residents evacuated and hatchery fish were urgently relocated. Photo by California Department of Water Resources, 2017.

2017.name: Record Sierran snowpack
captions: In spring of 2017, record snowpack in Soda Springs (near Donner Pass in the Sierra Nevada) consumes a home.

2017.name: Yuba River roils
captions: High flows reached 40x the normal rate on the South Yuba River after a series of atmospheric river storms in January 2017.

2017.name: Sacramento Weir opens
captions: The Sacramento Weir, built in 1916, protects the City of Sacramento from floods by diverting the Sacramento River flows into the Yolo Bypass. It is only opened manually during very large floods. In 2017, the gates were open for 17 days in January, then again for 2 days in February. They had not been opened since 2007.

2021.name: Lake Oroville breaks records
captions: The Bidwell Bar Bridge and nearby marina on Lake Oroville at record-breaking low water. In September 2021, water storage in the reservoir was 25 percent of the total capacity. By this time, the spillway of the Oroville Dam had been reconstructed after hazardous failures during floods of 2017.

2023.name: Tulare Lake returns
captions: Storms in March 2023 filled much of Tulare Lake, which had been dry for over 100 years. Once the largest freshwater lake west of the Mississippi River, Tulare Lake vanished by the late 1800's due to diversions for water supply. The lake, known as 'Pa-ashi' or 'big water' has been inhabited by the Tachi Yakuts people, who were forcibly removed during the Gold Rush. In 2023, the Tachi Yakuts honored the lake's return.
